bug.short_desc: calling "focus" on a DOM element results in unwanted scroll into view in IE

long_desc.thetext: Steps to reproduce: 1) Move a window outside the view. 2) Disengage the mouse button. 3) Click on the window title. -> The the view is moved automatically.

I have a similar problem with the table widget when It's used as an inline application. When the global window view (IE6 and IE7 have the same problem) is smaller than the inline table, selecting an hidden cell or trying to scroll the table after a lateral X-scrolling of the global <body> container makes this global scroller jump at the relative (0,alpha) position of the table.
I tried to tweak with specific css the isle container in order to see if there was a fast solution but it didn't help so far.
Here's a small video that much better explain the problem: http://s1.qshare.com/get/813083/ie-behaviour.avi.html.

I seems like IE automatically scrolls elements into view if you call "focus()" on them. This is regardless of the parent's overflow style. I know no way to fix it since we can't remove the focus call.

The problematic focus calls are in qx.event.handler.Focus Line 874 and line 218. It's obvious that we need to call "focus" on native form elements like text fields but do we really have to call it on DIVs?

We have to call it on DIVs as this creates the needed blur() on other elements (to remove the caret from the previously focused text field.
I know about the issue, but do not think is it fixable or even needed. What's so wrong with the behavior? It makes no sense to focus something which is not visible IMO.

Changed bug title.
Was: Auto scrolling in Desktop demo if set a window outside the visual view.
I see now way how this can be fixed.
